overview: James is practical wisdom for Christian living. Faith must show itself in works—controlling speech, caring for the poor, resisting favoritism, and patient endurance. It's Christianity with sleeves rolled up.

verses.text: Count it all joy, my brothers, when you meet trials of various kinds, for you know that the testing of your faith produces steadfastness.
So also faith by itself, if it does not have works, is dead.
Know this, my beloved brothers: let every person be quick to hear, slow to speak, slow to anger.
Draw near to God, and he will draw near to you.
Therefore, confess your sins to one another and pray for one another, that you may be healed. The prayer of a righteous person has great power as it is working.

passages.title: Faith and Works
passages.summary: Faith without works is dead—genuine faith shows itself in action. Abraham and Rahab are examples.

passages.title: Taming the Tongue
passages.summary: The tongue is a small member but causes great harm. No one can tame it, yet it must be controlled.

facts.text: James was Jesus' brother who became leader of the Jerusalem church, though he hadn't believed during Jesus' ministry.
Martin Luther called James an 'epistle of straw' because it seemed to contradict Paul on faith and works. Most see them as complementary.
James is the most practical book in the New Testament—nearly every verse is a command or instruction.
The book reads like Old Testament wisdom literature, especially Proverbs, applied to Christian living.

figures.name: James
figures.description: Jesus' half-brother who became a pillar of the Jerusalem church, known for his godliness and practical wisdom.

videos.title: James Overview
videos.description: The Bible Project explores how genuine faith shows itself in how we live.
